trans-unit.source: Working with Files and Folders
trans-unit.target: Working with Files and Folders

trans-unit.source: powershell,cmdlet
trans-unit.target: powershell,cmdlet

trans-unit.source: Working with Files and Folders
trans-unit.target: Working with Files and Folders

trans-unit.source: Navigating through Windows PowerShell drives and manipulating the items on them is similar to manipulating files and folders on Windows physical disk drives.
trans-unit.target: Navigating through Windows PowerShell drives and manipulating the items on them is similar to manipulating files and folders on Windows physical disk drives.

trans-unit.source: We will discuss how to deal with specific file and folder manipulation tasks in this section.
trans-unit.target: We will discuss how to deal with specific file and folder manipulation tasks in this section.

trans-unit.source: Listing All the Files and Folders Within a Folder
trans-unit.target: Listing All the Files and Folders Within a Folder

trans-unit.source: You can get all items directly within a folder by using **Get-ChildItem**.
trans-unit.target: You can get all items directly within a folder by using **Get-ChildItem**.

trans-unit.source: Add the optional **Force** parameter to display hidden or system items.
trans-unit.target: Add the optional **Force** parameter to display hidden or system items.

trans-unit.source: For example, this command displays the direct contents of Windows PowerShell Drive C (which is the same as the Windows physical drive C):
trans-unit.target: For example, this command displays the direct contents of Windows PowerShell Drive C (which is the same as the Windows physical drive C):

trans-unit.source: The command lists only the directly contained items, much like using Cmd.exe's **DIR** command or **ls** in a UNIX shell.
trans-unit.target: The command lists only the directly contained items, much like using Cmd.exe's **DIR** command or **ls** in a UNIX shell.

trans-unit.source: In order to show contained items, you need to specify the **-Recurse** parameter as well.
trans-unit.target: In order to show contained items, you need to specify the **-Recurse** parameter as well.

trans-unit.source: (This can take an extremely long time to complete.) To list everything on the C drive:
trans-unit.target: (This can take an extremely long time to complete.) To list everything on the C drive:

trans-unit.source: **Get-ChildItem** can filter items with its **Path**, **Filter**, **Include**, and **Exclude** parameters, but those are typically based only on name.
trans-unit.target: **Get-ChildItem** can filter items with its **Path**, **Filter**, **Include**, and **Exclude** parameters, but those are typically based only on name.

trans-unit.source: You can perform complex filtering based on other properties of items by using **Where-Object**.
trans-unit.target: You can perform complex filtering based on other properties of items by using **Where-Object**.

trans-unit.source: The following command finds all executables within the Program Files folder that were last modified after October 1, 2005 and which are neither smaller than 1 megabyte nor larger than 10 megabytes:
trans-unit.target: The following command finds all executables within the Program Files folder that were last modified after October 1, 2005 and which are neither smaller than 1 megabyte nor larger than 10 megabytes:

trans-unit.source: Copying Files and Folders
trans-unit.target: Copying Files and Folders

trans-unit.source: Copying is done with **Copy-Item**.
trans-unit.target: Copying is done with **Copy-Item**.

trans-unit.source: The following command backs up C:\\boot.ini to C:\\boot.bak:
trans-unit.target: The following command backs up C:\\boot.ini to C:\\boot.bak:

trans-unit.source: If the destination file already exists, the copy attempt fails.
trans-unit.target: If the destination file already exists, the copy attempt fails.

trans-unit.source: To overwrite a pre-existing destination, use the Force parameter:
trans-unit.target: To overwrite a pre-existing destination, use the Force parameter:

trans-unit.source: This command works even when the destination is read-only.
trans-unit.target: This command works even when the destination is read-only.

trans-unit.source: Folder copying works the same way.
trans-unit.target: Folder copying works the same way.

trans-unit.source: This command copies the folder C:\\temp\\test1 to the new folder c:\\temp\\DeleteMe recursively:
trans-unit.target: This command copies the folder C:\\temp\\test1 to the new folder c:\\temp\\DeleteMe recursively:

trans-unit.source: You can also copy a selection of items.
trans-unit.target: You can also copy a selection of items.

trans-unit.source: The following command copies all .txt files contained anywhere in c:\\data to c:\\temp\\text:
trans-unit.target: The following command copies all .txt files contained anywhere in c:\\data to c:\\temp\\text:

trans-unit.source: You can still use other tools to perform file system copies.
trans-unit.target: You can still use other tools to perform file system copies.

trans-unit.source: XCOPY, ROBOCOPY, and COM objects, such as the **Scripting.FileSystemObject,** all work in Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: XCOPY, ROBOCOPY, and COM objects, such as the **Scripting.FileSystemObject,** all work in Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can use the Windows Script Host **Scripting.FileSystem COM** class to back up C:\\boot.ini to C:\\boot.bak:
trans-unit.target: For example, you can use the Windows Script Host **Scripting.FileSystem COM** class to back up C:\\boot.ini to C:\\boot.bak:

trans-unit.source: Creating Files and Folders
trans-unit.target: Creating Files and Folders

trans-unit.source: Creating new items works the same on all Windows PowerShell providers.
trans-unit.target: Creating new items works the same on all Windows PowerShell providers.

trans-unit.source: If a Windows PowerShell provider has more than one type of item—for example, the FileSystem Windows PowerShell provider distinguishes between directories and files—you need to specify the item type.
trans-unit.target: If a Windows PowerShell provider has more than one type of item—for example, the FileSystem Windows PowerShell provider distinguishes between directories and files—you need to specify the item type.

trans-unit.source: This command creates a new folder C:\\temp\\New Folder:
trans-unit.target: This command creates a new folder C:\\temp\\New Folder:

trans-unit.source: This command creates a new empty file C:\\temp\\New Folder\\file.txt
trans-unit.target: This command creates a new empty file C:\\temp\\New Folder\\file.txt

trans-unit.source: Removing All Files and Folders Within a Folder
trans-unit.target: Removing All Files and Folders Within a Folder

trans-unit.source: You can remove contained items using **Remove-Item**, but you will be prompted to confirm the removal if the item contains anything else.
trans-unit.target: You can remove contained items using **Remove-Item**, but you will be prompted to confirm the removal if the item contains anything else.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you attempt to delete the folder C:\\temp\\DeleteMe that contains other items, Windows PowerShell prompts you for confirmation before deleting the folder:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you attempt to delete the folder C:\\temp\\DeleteMe that contains other items, Windows PowerShell prompts you for confirmation before deleting the folder:

trans-unit.source: If you do not want to be prompted for each contained item, specify the **Recurse** parameter:
trans-unit.target: If you do not want to be prompted for each contained item, specify the **Recurse** parameter:

trans-unit.source: Mapping a Local Folder as a Windows Accessible Drive
trans-unit.target: Mapping a Local Folder as a Windows Accessible Drive

trans-unit.source: You can also map a local folder, using the **subst** command.
trans-unit.target: You can also map a local folder, using the **subst** command.

trans-unit.source: The following command creates a local drive P: rooted in the local Program Files directory:
trans-unit.target: The following command creates a local drive P: rooted in the local Program Files directory:

trans-unit.source: Just as with network drives, drives mapped within Windows PowerShell using **subst** are immediately visible to the Windows PowerShell shell.
trans-unit.target: Just as with network drives, drives mapped within Windows PowerShell using **subst** are immediately visible to the Windows PowerShell shell.

trans-unit.source: Reading a Text File into an Array
trans-unit.target: Reading a Text File into an Array

trans-unit.source: One of the more common storage formats for text data is in a file with separate lines treated as distinct data elements.
trans-unit.target: One of the more common storage formats for text data is in a file with separate lines treated as distinct data elements.

trans-unit.source: The **Get-Content** cmdlet can be used to read an entire file in one step, as shown here:
trans-unit.target: The **Get-Content** cmdlet can be used to read an entire file in one step, as shown here:

trans-unit.source: **Get-Content** already treats the data read from the file as an array, with one element per line of file content.
trans-unit.target: **Get-Content** already treats the data read from the file as an array, with one element per line of file content.

trans-unit.source: You can confirm this by checking the **Length** of the returned content:
trans-unit.target: You can confirm this by checking the **Length** of the returned content:

trans-unit.source: This command is most useful for getting lists of information into Windows PowerShell directly.
trans-unit.target: This command is most useful for getting lists of information into Windows PowerShell directly.

trans-unit.source: For example, you might store a list of computer names or IP addresses in a file C:\\temp\\domainMembers.txt, with one name on each line of the file.
trans-unit.target: For example, you might store a list of computer names or IP addresses in a file C:\\temp\\domainMembers.txt, with one name on each line of the file.

trans-unit.source: You can use **Get-Content** to retrieve the file contents and put them in the variable **$Computers**:
trans-unit.target: You can use **Get-Content** to retrieve the file contents and put them in the variable **$Computers**:

trans-unit.source: **$Computers** is now an array containing a computer name in each element.
trans-unit.target: **$Computers** is now an array containing a computer name in each element.
